author: Dan Gunderman
title: Dictionary posts definition of 'feminism' following Conway speech
text:
Merriam-Webster posts definition of ‘feminism’ following Kellyanne Conway’s puzzling take on it in CPAC speech Dictionary posts definition of 'feminism' following Conway speech White House counselor Kellyanne Conway speaks at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in Oxon Hill, Md., Thursday, Feb. 23, 2017. (Susan Walsh/AP)   1:03 PM 
Hmm, equal pay but disorganization? 
During her controversial speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) on Thursday, Kellyanne Conway slammed modern feminism and attempted to describe her version of “conservative” feminism. 
Following President Donald Trump’s senior counselor’s speech, Merriam-Webster dictionary took to social media to address the immediate spike in lookups for “feminism.” A crowd fills Independence Avenue during the Women's March on Washington, Saturday, Jan. 21, 2017 in Washington. (Alex Brandon/AP) 
The site wrote that Conway “both called for equal pay for women and said that she didn’t identify herself as a feminist.” 
Kellyanne Conway slams feminism as 'anti-male' and 'pro-abortion' 
Merriam-Webster, after describing Conway’s own definition of the term, was sure to remind visitors what “feminism” means: the word is described “as both ‘the belief that men and women should have equal rights and opportunities’ and ‘organized activity in support of women’s rights and interests.’” 
The site continued by posting, “It entered the language in 1895, at a time when efforts for women’s political equality were becoming organized and widespread in England and the United States.” 
In Conway’s speech, deriding feminism in the modern sense for having been co-opted by the left and being “very anti-male” and “certainly very pro-abortion,” she declared for a sort of “individual feminism.” 
Conway touted herself as a “product of my choices, not a victim of my circumstances.” She described that as “conservative feminism.” 
She also said that, “One thing that’s been a little disappointing and revealing that I hope will get better is it turns out a lot of women just have a problem with women in power...” 
Conway also spoke about her blue-collar upbringing and how her mother “didn’t feel sorry for herself.” Kellyanne Conway appears prior to a forum at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government in Cambridge, Mass. in December. (Charles Krupa/AP) 
She also advised women how to succeed in the workplace — especially in striving for equal pay. 
Conway has faced recent backlash over her cable TV appearances — ones in which she appeared to be on a different page than other White House staffers. 
University takes aim at alumna Kellyanne Conway 
Among those in Trump’s cabinet, Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos, Chief Strategist Steve Bannon and Chief of Staff Reince Priebus are also scheduled to speak at CPAC. 
In addition to the Merriam-Webster tweet, social media has teed off on the embattled Conway. Here’s a look at some of the best responses to her speech: 📈'Feminism' is defined as "the belief that men and women should have equal rights and opportunities." https://t.co/Zjf7CAPUjL
